author: DamianEdwards
body:
Today the Aspire shared project that gets added to all Aspire solutions and auto-referenced by Aspire service projects depends on ASP.NET Core. This leads to issues for service projects that aren't ASP.NET Core projects, e.g. Blazor WebAssembly projects, JSPS projects (SPA), Worker projects, etc.

We need to figure out what the story is for shared code in service projects that aren't ASP.NET Core projects.

nodes.author: dbreshears
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards , triaging DevEx,  this should probalby be assigned to someone on runtime team?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Yah, can assign to me

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
[A sample has been added that integrates client apps (WinForms & WPF) in an AppHost project](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/tree/main/samples/ClientAppsIntegration). It includes an example of refactoring the ServiceDefaults project to depend on a new AppDefaults project that doesn't have the framework dependency on ASP.NET Core. The client apps depend on the AppDefaults project and the server apps depend on ServiceDefaults.

We might want to consider updating VS to properly support solutions with multiple projects that have `<IsAspireSharedProject>true</IsAspireSharedProject>` so that there's a better experience for this kind of pattern and the VS tooling auto-selects/prompts-for which shared project to reference when adding Aspire orchestration to an app project.

/Cc @phenning

nodes.author: phenning
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards so would we want to have the AppDefaults project also set IsAspireSharedProject and use the presence of the Microsoft.AspNetCore.App framework reference to determine which to use for client vs server apps?

nodes.author: phenning
nodes.body: We'd obviously also need the desired scaffolded code for each type of client app. This is probably a significantly sized work item that needs to be added to the tooling backlog.

nodes.author: phenning
nodes.body: @vijayrkn  FYI

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: @phenning For now I'm just proposing that we unblock this scenario a bit by supporting multiple shared projects in the VS UI and letting the user pick. We could add a bit of extra logic to auto-select (but still allow selection) one based on the framework reference, and if being added to a project that doesn't have a framework reference to ASP.NET Core, we could simply disable the code-generation and show a message to that effect.

nodes.author: phenning
nodes.body:
I think we need to fully flesh out the desired experience for client-based projects before making any changes here. If we only do what you are suggesting here wouldn't really buy us anything on its own.

What happens if the user picks the server service default shared project when they should have picked the app centric one, and we insert the wrong code?

Also, consider that a standalone WPF app in a solution on its own does not even have the option of adding the orchestration to it currently - we need to fix that as well.

If you do Add Aspire Orchestrator support into a WPF app into a solution which does have an app host/shared project, it will add the service defaults project as a reference, but doesn't add any code to the WPF app or add anything to the AppHost project (not even a project reference).

Keep in mind that if/when we do add a picker for the defaults project, we would need to have it both in NPD and in the UI for when we do it via context menu.  Do we expect users to have more than two "defaults" projects - one for services and one for apps? Is there a scenario where they would want to pick the app defaults for a service project or vice versa?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
> What happens if the user picks the server service default shared project when they should have picked the app centric one, and we insert the wrong code?

Then it doesn't compile. This is about making an incremental improvement to the current experience even if it leaves ultimate responsibility to the developer.

> Also, consider that a standalone WPF app in a solution on its own does not even have the option of adding the orchestration to it currently - we need to fix that as well.

> If you do Add Aspire Orchestrator support into a WPF app into a solution which does have an app host/shared project, it will add the service defaults project as a reference, but doesn't add any code to the WPF app or add anything to the AppHost project (not even a project reference).

This is my point, right now the experience only works for web projects, but Aspire itself is not at all limited to that, and indeed things like Worker projects should work but don't. I know the MAUI folks are looking at how to better integrate into the Aspire experience too. If we open up the Aspire UX to all project types, the minimum we'd need to do in my mind is allow the user to select which defaults library project to use (including "none"). Adding a project reference to the AppHost project would always be required.

> Keep in mind that if/when we do add a picker for the defaults project, we would need to have it both in NPD and in the UI for when we do it via context menu. Do we expect users to have more than two "defaults" projects - one for services and one for apps? Is there a scenario where they would want to pick the app defaults for a service project or vice versa?

Yep we'd need it in both flows. I think the next click-stop is simply to prompt the developer for which defaults library project to use, including none at all.

nodes.author: joperezr
nodes.body: Moving to Preview 5 in favor of removing milestone preview TBD.

nodes.author: bradygaster
nodes.body: Agreed with @phenning we should carve out the e2e experience for this. @DamianEdwards i think you mentioned having a sample earlier in the thread demonstrative of this scenario, i'd like to take a look and understand the goals here better.

nodes.author: bradygaster
nodes.body: To be clear, when we say "Shared" project in this thread, we're specifically referring to the `ServiceDefaults` project, right? cc @DamianEdwards just to clarify.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: @bradygaster yeah it's the https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/tree/main/samples/ClientAppsIntegration sample. Note that  it has two different defaults projects: AppDefaults, and ServiceDefaults. I'm proposing we make the UI changes necessary in VS to allow them both to be marked as `<IsAspireSharedProject>true</IsAspireSharedProject>`.

nodes.author: bradygaster
nodes.body:
The more I think about this the more I think we need this sooner rather than later and that the work won't be that complicated. I'll do some thinking. 

I organized the references in the same order to think about it; essentially the difference is "we want a second option for a service defaults that doesn't depend on an of the ASP.NET Core" libraries. For Worker, that makes HUGE sense. For WASM, I think it does too; we know these are project types cloud-native customers will/should want to use in their development. 

I'll work through some screens.

author: thomas-girotto
body:
Hello Aspire team,

After a fresh dotnet new aspire-starter, I couldn't see any OTEL data in the dashboard...

After activating the OTEL logs (with OTEL_DIAGNOSTICS.json), i was able to see that the dotnet projects failed pushing data to the OTEL server with the following error:

Exporter failed send data to collector to {0} endpoint. Data will not be sent. Exception: {1}{http://localhost:16159/}{Grpc.Core.RpcException: Status(StatusCode="Internal", Detail="Error starting gRPC call. HttpRequestException: Requesting HTTP version 2.0 with version policy RequestVersionOrHigher while unable to establish HTTP/2 connection.", DebugException="System.Net.Http.HttpRequestException: Requesting HTTP version 2.0 with version policy RequestVersionOrHigher while unable to establish HTTP/2 connection.")
 ---> System.Net.Http.HttpRequestException: Requesting HTTP version 2.0 with version policy RequestVersionOrHigher while unable to establish HTTP/2 connection.
   at System.Net.Http.HttpConnectionPool.SendWithVersionDetectionAndRetryAsync(HttpRequestMessage request, Boolean async, Boolean doRequestAuth, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at System.Net.Http.DiagnosticsHandler.SendAsyncCore(HttpRequestMessage request, Boolean async, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at System.Net.Http.Metrics.MetricsHandler.SendAsyncWithMetrics(HttpRequestMessage request, Boolean async, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at System.Net.Http.RedirectHandler.SendAsync(HttpRequestMessage request, Boolean async, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at Grpc.Net.Client.Balancer.Internal.BalancerHttpHandler.SendAsync(HttpRequestMessage request, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at Grpc.Net.Client.Internal.GrpcCall`2.RunCall(HttpRequestMessage request, Nullable`1 timeout)
   --- End of inner exception stack trace ---
   at Grpc.Net.Client.Internal.HttpClientCallInvoker.BlockingUnaryCall[TRequest,TResponse](Method`2 method, String host, CallOptions options, TRequest request)
   at Grpc.Core.Interceptors.InterceptingCallInvoker.<BlockingUnaryCall>b__3_0[TRequest,TResponse](TRequest req, ClientInterceptorContext`2 ctx)
   at Grpc.Core.Interceptors.InterceptingCallInvoker.BlockingUnaryCall[TRequest,TResponse](Method`2 method, String host, CallOptions options, TRequest request)
   at OpenTelemetry.Proto.Collector.Metrics.V1.MetricsService.MetricsServiceClient.Export(ExportMetricsServiceRequest request, Metadata headers, Nullable`1 deadline, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at OpenTelemetry.Exporter.OpenTelemetryProtocol.Implementation.ExportClient.OtlpGrpcMetricsExportClient.SendExportRequest(ExportMetricsServiceRequest request, CancellationToken cancellationToken)}

That was because of my local setup: i'm using PX proxy, and HTTP_PROXY and HTTPS_PROXY were set to http://localhost:3128 (my px port).

By adding HTTP_PROXY="" and HTTPS_PROXY="" in all the launchSettings.json, it finally worked (but it actually took me a lot of time to figure out how to solve this !)

Maybe you could document that somewhere, or add HTTP_PROXY="" in the default template? 

It is a pretty common scenario in enterprise to have this kind of proxy setup on your computer.

Thank you for the great job with Aspire, now that it works i can't wait to use it for real !

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: cc @samsp-msft @JamesNK

nodes.author: danmoseley
nodes.body: @JamesNK Is there work here for GA?

nodes.author: JamesNK
nodes.body:
I'm not sure. HttpClient interaction with proxies isn't something I know a lot about.

@karelz Is there existing documentation about making HTTP requests between localhost apps when a proxy is configured?

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
Moving this to P5 for investigation.

cc @MihaZupan

nodes.author: MihaZupan
nodes.body:
We don't currently allow non-https traffic to use HTTP/2 when talking through an http/https proxy.

I don't think there's a fundamental technical limitation here that would prevent us from allowing that when Exact/OrHigher version is specified, I think it just hasn't come up yet.
For example, we'll let you tunnel H2 through a socks proxy without encryption, so I don't see why we wouldn't allow it for http proxies.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: We should move this to a dotnet/runtime then correct?

nodes.author: JamesNK
nodes.body:
> We don't currently allow non-https traffic to use HTTP/2 when talking through an http/https proxy.

What should we tell people who run into this error? I don't think setting values in launchSettings.json will be enough. The Aspire dashboard needs to talk to the hosting over HTTP/2, and also all the apps need to talk to the dashboard over HTTP/2.

nodes.author: MihaZupan
nodes.body:
Filed https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/99689 to track it there.

The current workarounds would be:
- Use https if possible?
- Don't use a proxy for these requests
- Use a SOCKS proxy instead of HTTP if supported by the proxy

nodes.author: MihaZupan
nodes.body: Is this important for .NET 9.0 for Aspire?

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Hard to tell, if customers run into it, it seems like there's no workaround? So from that POV yes? On the other hand, not many people have reported it.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Moving to backlog

author: AndriySvyryd
body: Based on https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/tree/main/samples/DatabaseMigrations/DatabaseMigrations.MigrationService with placeholders for provider-specific code

nodes.author: davidfowl

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Or we could just add it to the existing starter template, potentially as an option.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
Strawman with some open questions:

We get a lot of feedback about what patterns work well to configure, initialize, and manage a database using EF Core as part of an Aspire app. We have [some](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/tree/main/samples/DatabaseMigrations) [samples](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/tree/main/samples/AspireShop/AspireShop.CatalogDbManager) and [documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/aspire/database/ef-core-migrations) on this but we should take this guidance to the next level and include it in our starter template.

Rough idea of what this would include:
- A new option on the template to include a database that allows selecting between the supported database integrations: PostgreSQL, MS SQL Server, MySQL, MongoDB, or Oracle
  -  ❓ Should we limit this to just PostgreSQL and MS SQL Server? Some other combo? 
- A simple page in the Blazor app that uses the database and demonstrates basic CRUD, e.g. a Todo's list
- A new API in the API project that exposes an HTTP API for the data in the database (this aligns with the webapiaot template so we can lift the relevant implementation from there)
  - ❓ Should this be a new API added in the existing project or should we separate into its own API project?
- A new worker service project to own and run the migrations based on the [existing sample](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/tree/main/samples/DatabaseMigrations)
- Relevant code in the AppHost project to add the database server and instance resources, the new worker service project, and configure the API & worker service projects to reference the database resource and `WaitFor` it
- Update the tests project to add a test that hits the page that depends on the database

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
> ❓ Should we limit this to just PostgreSQL and MS SQL Server? Some other combo?

1. PostgreSQL, MS SQL Server

> A new API in the API project that exposes an HTTP API for the data in the database (this aligns with the webapiaot template so we can lift the relevant implementation from there)

Yes, we should do the DB stuff in existing API not from the front end directly.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
First cut of what it would look like is at https://github.com/DamianEdwards/AspireStarterDb
I made the migrations service a web project as we don't support deploying worker apps to ACA today.
Please provide any feedback and I'll work to get this added to the 9.0 starter template.

nodes.body:
It should use the new [`UseAsyncSeeding`](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/blob/release/9.0/src/EFCore/DbContextOptionsBuilder.cs#L774) for seeding. `HasData` is rarely what the users want, it's for managed data that evolves with the model but is never modified by the application itself.
And apply the other suggestions from https://github.com/dotnet/aspire-samples/issues/401

### Is there an existing issue for this?

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

Metrics exemplars are off by default. `opentelemetry-dotnet` decided to do this because there is a small perf cost to collecting them.

In Aspire, exemplars are enabled locally via an env var that is set on .NET projects. However, this won't be applied after deployment.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Enable exemplars in service defaults template. This would be some configuration of `opentelemetry-dotnet`.

### Additional context

_No response_

title: Consider enabling exemplars in template service defaults

author: alrz
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

Currently there's distinction between external components and internal projects, in a microservice setting you most likely don't have all the services inside the same solution. A "component template" or "external project" would fill this gap where a service is being developed that others can connect and interact with.

### Describe the solution you'd like

The template would be set up in such a way that it can be packaged for other services to depend on. Just like components, these services could be hosted locally or connect to a live instance. 



### Additional context

Note this is a rough idea perhaps there's a way to do this today but I think it's worth considering it as a first-class building block.

nodes.author: alrz
nodes.body: I think what could accompany this is a "aspire library template" as a centralized package that services could depend on. It would include the defaults and all the definition from internal and external components that underlying services in a cluster could use.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Let me know if I am interpreting this correctly: You want to be able to package up a project as an aspire resource and have other services on the team use it?

nodes.author: alrz
nodes.body:
> Let me know if I am interpreting this correctly: You want to be able to package up a project as an aspire resource and have other services on the team use it?

That's exactly correct. To elaborate, right now an aspire project would consist of the following:

Solution0
 - ProjectA
 - ProjectB
 - ServiceDefaults
 - AppHost

--

Suppose ProjectA and ProjectB and optionally ServiceDefaults are developed separately, then the structured is factored into:

Solution0
- ServiceDefaults (package, shared)

Solution1
- ProjectA
- AppHost
- Hosting (package)
- Client / Component (package)

Solution2
- ProjectB
- AppHost
- Hosting (package)
- Client / Component (package)

This way, ProjectA can use Hosting and Component packages from ProjectB while being a completely separate codebase.

It's important to be able to connect to a live instance (e.g. staging endpoint) as well as spinning up the image from hosting package.

--

Note Hosting and Component packages don't have to live close to the actual project and can be deployed separately.

Solution0 (shared packages)
- ServiceDefaults 
- ProjectA Hosting
- ProjectB Hosting
- ProjectA Component
- ProjectB Component

Solution1
- ProjectA
- AppHost

Solution2
- ProjectB
- AppHost

The shared packages are already a common practice to avoid code duplication which I think aspire could encourage.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Interesting idea that would require some more exploration of what the patterns might look like. Putting on the backlog for now but I'd be interested in seeing any prototypes or further thoughts folks had.

nodes.author: alrz
nodes.body:
> require some more exploration of what the patterns might look like.

Couldn't every component that aspire supports right now be considered as an example of this? Integrations/Components are currently developed only around reusable service/libraries, and this is a request to open that up to aspnet apps as well.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
@DamianEdwards is saying that someone should go build it and figure it out, then update the issue with more details. It’s not a focus area for us at the moment, we are bashing bugs and tackling areas of high user feedback.

This is something we want to do, just not now. That could be sped up with more investigation and details about the options.

Off the top of my head I can think of a few things that we would want to understand before making this a template: 

- How do you package the application? Custom format? Docker/OCI image/dotnet tool? (PS: I like the idea of putting the OCI/docker image in a nuget package but have yet to try it)
- Is this just about the application or is it about encapsulating dependencies as well? (Microservice as an integration).
- I can see a future where you build an application where your application becomes a hosting integration and you generate a client library (rest/grpc) and that becomes your client integration. 

The next step here is to go build a repository sharing what the options would look like and what we might need to change in the core to make it work well.

title: Add aspire integration template

author: martincostello
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

Via https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/4110#issuecomment-2307659159.

Kubernetes supports [three types of health probes](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/configuration/liveness-readiness-startup-probes/):
- Liveness
- Readiness
- Startup

It would be useful for application developers if the Aspire service defaults configured distinct Health Check endpoints that correspond to these concepts, ready for the developer to plug in the appropriate specific health checks that are required for their application.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Provide health endpoints for each type of probe, such as:

- `/health/liveness` or `/health/live`
- `/health/readiness` or `/health/ready`
- `/health/startup`

By default these could effectively all just be a "live" health check with no specificity, and the application developer can extend each one as-appropriate for their needs. If for a simple application only one endpoint is really needed, the default would serve to inform developers of the concept and distinction between different types of health probes when deploying containers to Kubernetes.


### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: @davidfowl do you recall why we didn't do this in the first place? Seems this is a pretty widely accepted approach.

nodes.author: wertzui
nodes.body:
I've just implemented this on my own in 2 NuGet Packages.
- [HealthChecks.Kubernetes.Aspire](https://www.nuget.org/packages/HealthChecks.Kubernetes.Aspire) which you can add to your Application to expose the 3 endpoints.
- [HealthChecks.Kubernetes.Aspire.Hosting](https://www.nuget.org/packages/HealthChecks.Kubernetes.Aspire.Hosting/) which you then add to your Aspire AppHost project to consume the health checks and display the status on the Aspire dashboard.

See https://github.com/wertzui/Aspire.HealthChecks.Kubernetes for examples on how to use it, It's just 2 extension methods, one for the `IApplicationBuilder` and one for `IResourceBuilder<T>`.

title: Expose default health endpoints for Kubernetes probes

author: DamianEdwards
body: The correct term for the app host project is "app host project". When used in a situation that dictates PascalCase, e.g. project names, this becomes "AppHost". Title case would be "App host". We aren't consistent throughout the product today, e.g. in warning messages, template titles and descriptions, doc comments, etc., and should clean them up.

nodes.author: IEvangelist
nodes.body: In docs, we strive to be consistent with our usage. When speaking about it conceptually, we call it "app host". When we refer to it in the content of the project itself, we say "AppHost". We do use the heading "App host usage" in integration docs, but that's because we're talking about it conceptually and we're required to use sentence case in headings in docs.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Thanks @IEvangelist. So how would it be used when referring to the project in the conceptual/generic sense, rather than a specific example? i.e. "Update your app host project to..." or "Update your AppHost project to..."? IIUC I'm thinking it's the former?

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: How should we refer to it in XML docs (just checking for future because I know I've been inconsistent).

nodes.author: danmoseley
nodes.body: @IEvangelist could you asnwer q's above?

title: Ensure correct term is used when referring to the app host project

author: eerhardt
body:
We haven't updated our dependeny on OpenTelemetry past `1.9.0` because `1.10.0` introduces dependencies that "lift" assemblies out of the shared framework. See [[bug] targets other than net9.0 shouldn't be forced to use 9.0 dependencies (open-telemetry/opentelemetry-dotnet#5973)](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-dotnet/issues/5973) for more information.

We should decide what to do with this dependency. The major consumer of these packages is our templates in the ServiceDefaults project.

1. Should we upgrade to the new version even though we know it will "lift" Microsoft.Extensions.*, System.Diagnostics.DiagnosticsSource, •	System.IO.Pipelines, System.Text.Encodings.Web, and System.Text.Json assemblies out of the shared framework?

2. Should we stay on the 1.9.0 version, and customers can update to the new versions if they want?

3. Should we split based on the TFM, and only use the new version if the app is targeting `net9.0`?

cc @joperezr @DamianEdwards @samsp-msft

nodes.author: hdost
nodes.body: Might be worth talking to some of your coworkers about fixing the OTel upstream side 🤷‍♂️.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
> Should we split based on the TFM, and only use the new version if the app is targeting net9.0?

These seems like a reasonable thing to do as we can do it in the template source so new projects on `net9.0` get OTel >1.9.0 and `net8.0` gets 1.9.0.

nodes.author: sebastienros
nodes.body:
+1 on splitting based on the TFM

In this case the split is not too disruptive either (a few conditionals in code)

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: @eerhardt should we do the template fix to bump the OTel versions to latest when targeting `net9.0` in 9.2?

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body:
> [@eerhardt](https://github.com/eerhardt) should we do the template fix to bump the OTel versions to latest when targeting `net9.0` in 9.2?

We can. It wouldn't hurt to update to the latest when you are targeting `net9.0`.

title: .NET Aspire is stuck on OpenTelemetry 1.9.0

author: jongio
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

After the user creates a new Aspire project from a template it would be good to let them know what to do next.  If they hit F5, they are presented with the option to run C#, which makes sense, but then they are presented with option to run all of the projects in the solution, and it may not be apparent that they need to run the AppHost project, especially for new users.



### Describe the solution you'd like

Suggest adding a launch.json with the AppHost Default Configuration wired up.  Or a "Next Steps" md file that can help them through that.  Also, recommend adding that they will likely need to close down all browsers after installing the dev cert.

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards thoughts?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
Yeah VS has the Aspire "starter" page that is auto-displayed after creating Aspire projects but we don't have anything anywhere else. I think a `nextsteps.md` or something similar could be interesting, especially if we can figure out how to make it auto-open so it's presented more "forcibly" as the next thing the user should read (i.e. in VS Code, etc.). I'm curious as to whether there's already an established pattern or standard for this kind of thing?

RE the "if they hit F5 they have to select C#, etc." I'm empathetic to that but the VS Code launch space is kinda complex, with some stacks preferring to default to dynamic (in-memory) launch providers vs. being driven by `launch.json`/`tasks.json`. Not sure how to resolve that.

author: MermaidIsla
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

This bug is related to #8580. Creating a custom health check class that implements `IHealthCheck` interface with an HTTP call to another service causes health check spam in the Dashboard's Traces tab. Even after applying a fix from #8643 the issue still persists.

### Expected Behavior

No health check spam.

### Steps To Reproduce

GitHub repo: https://github.com/MermaidIsla/aspire-health-check-bug/

**Steps to reproduce this bug**

1. Create a new project using the template `.NET Aspire Starter App`
2. In the `Web` project create a new class called `ApiServiceHealthCheck`
3. Copy the following code into `ApiServiceHealthCheck.cs` file:
```csharp
public class ApiServiceHealthCheck(HttpClient httpClient) : IHealthCheck
{
    public async Task<HealthCheckResult> CheckHealthAsync(HealthCheckContext context, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default)
    {
        var response = await httpClient.GetAsync("http://apiservice/health", cancellationToken).ConfigureAwait(false);

        return response.IsSuccessStatusCode ? HealthCheckResult.Healthy() : HealthCheckResult.Unhealthy();
    }
}
```
4. In the `Web` project open `Program.cs` file and add the following code `builder.Services.AddHealthChecks().AddCheck<ApiServiceHealthCheck>("apiservice");` just before `var app = builder.Build();`
5. In the `AppHost` project ensure that both projects (`apiservice` and `webfrontend`) have `.WithHttpHealthCheck("/health", 200, "http")`
6. Run the `AppHost` project, open the dashboard and click on `Traces` tab
7. You should now see a health check spam

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
OK so this is the client-side part causing the trace now, i.e. a health check registered in an app is registered and it calls out to an HTTP endpoint of another app/resource and the `HttpClient` traces the outgoing request, which ends up in the trace of the app issuing the request.

Rather than filtering based on outgoing path (which could suppress traces for non-health-check related calls), I think it'd be better if we could configure the `HttpClient` instance used by the health check to disable tracing. Not sure if that's possible but I'll take a look.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: BTW this isn't a regression from the 9.2 template change IIUC. This has always been the case if you add a health check from one app to another via HTTP.

title: HTTP Health check spam in telemetry when chaining health checks

We now have integrations for publishing Aspire apps to Azure (ACA, App Service), Kubernetes, and Docker Compose. Each of these requires the addition of extra NuGet packages and code in the AppHost.

author: jguadagno
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Working with a `Program.cs` that has a try/catch block in it where the `builder` object is built, the current Aspire templates place the `builder.AddServiceDefaults()` and the `builder.MapDefaultEndpoints()` outside the try/catch block causing the application to no longer compile.

### Expected Behavior

I would expect that the Aspire template detect the `builder` is being created inside a try/catch block and implement the required Aspire methods in the same block.

### Steps To Reproduce

My public repo of [contacts-noauth](https://github.com/jguadagno/contacts-noauth) is the starter point for this bug.  Using Visual Studio, add .NET Aspire Orchestration to the *Contacts.Api* project. It will work and create the *AppHost* and *ServiceDefaults* project, however, the project *Contacts.Api* will no longer compile.

If you look at [Program.cs](https://github.com/jguadagno/contacts-noauth/blob/main/src/Contacts.Api/Program.cs) you will notice there is a try block that starts on line [18](https://github.com/jguadagno/contacts-noauth/blob/b91f0ecb201f4f9a52e9b504d5dc36b43617173b/src/Contacts.Api/Program.cs#L18). The builder is created on line 20.  However, when running the Aspire .NET Orchestration adds the following lines

```csharp
builder.AddServiceDefaults();

builder.MapDefaultEndpoints();
```

to lines 49 and 51, outside the try/catch block where the `builder` object is not available.

_No response_

author: IEvangelist
body:
.NET backend but for sure, but a JS frontend would be great.

We have an opportunity to really set up a beautiful template, that demonstrates how to connect a .NET Minimal API to a React frontend (for example). Ideally, it would showcase:

```mermaid
architecture-beta
  group apphost(server)[AppHost]

  service db(database)[PostgreSQL DB] in apphost
  service api(internet)[API Service] in apphost
  service frontend(internet)[Web Frontend] in apphost
  service ai(cloud)[AI] in apphost

  api:R --> L:db
  frontend:R --> L:api
  ai:T <-- B:api
```

- `AppHost`:
  - `CommunityToolkit.Aspire.Hosting.NodeJS.Extensions`
  - `Aspire.Hosting.Azure.PostgreSQL` (Optional, allow vendor selection, Azure, AWS, Kubernetes)
  - AI (Ollama `run mode`, `-vendor` for `publish mode`)
  - Custom URL `/scalar` endpoint (Optional)
- API:
  - `Aspire.Azure.Npgsql.EntityFrameworkCore.PostgreSQL` (Optional, allow vendor selection, Azure, AWS, Kubernetes)
  - `Scalar.AspNetCore` (Optional)
  - Server-Sent Events
- Web:
  - Next.js (App Router)
  - Modern TODO App UX
  - Tailwind CSS
  - TypeScript

A user might call the template like this:

```
aspire new react-starter
```

The optional switches might be:

- `-vendor | -v`: `azure`, `aws`, `k8s`
- `-scalar | -s`: include scalar and custom endpoint URL
title: Consider a JavaScript frontend template

author: davidfowl
body:
The current "aspire update" CLI command only updates a single project's packages. To provide a complete update experience and ensure developer environments are correctly configured, enhance the "aspire update" command to:

- Remove the Aspire workload if present (since the CLI sits outside the workload and should decouple from it)
- Update the Aspire templates installed on the machine to the latest version
- Update the project's Aspire package references and scaffolding (current behavior)

This will allow users to run a single command to bring their machine and project into the right state for Aspire, eliminating duplication/conflicts and simplifying guidance/documentation for upgrades. The command should:
- Be idempotent: safe to run repeatedly
- Report what actions were taken (workload removal, template update, project update)
- Surface actionable errors if steps fail (e.g., workload uninstall issues)

This change will streamline the developer experience and ensure Aspire environments are reliably updated via the CLI.
title: Enhance aspire update command to update Aspire itself and fix developer environment state
